head.hi:
Interesting Correspondence with M. Alex.
de Humboldt.

div.p:
The Ocean Steam Navigation Company of this
city having determined to call the third and fourth
steamers of their line the Franklin and the Hum-
boldt, authorized their President, Mr. Sand, to in-
form M. de Humboldt of their intention, and beg
his sanction to giving his name to one of their ships.
The letter was forwarded to Berlin through the me-
dium of the Prussian Minister at Washington, M.
de Gerolt, and by the last arrival, the President of
the Company was favored with M. de Humboldt’s
reply, through the medium of Mr. Donelson, our
Minister at Berlin.

We have the pleasure of laying before our read-
ers a translation of this letter, containing so pleas-
ing an expression of the generous sentiments of one
of the greatest spirits of the age: —

To C. H. Sand, Esq, President of the Ocean Steam Nav.
Company, New York:

Mr. President—Through the medium of my old
friend, Mr. de Gerolt, our Minister in the United
States, I have to-day—while occupied with the pre-
parations for a journey to Paris—received the friend-
ly letter, dated 21st August, with which you have
been pleased to honor me. It informs me that a fa-
vor has just been conferred on me, of which I could
not believe myself worthy, of associating my name
with that of a great citizen, who, from my earliest
youth, has been the object of my liveliest admira-
tion. I venture to request you, sir, to present the
homage of my respectful acknowledgements to the
gentlemen directors of the Ocean Steam Navigation
Co., who, on the flattering motion of Mr. Stephens,
have determined that the fourth ship of their line of
mail steamers between New York and Bremen shall
bear my name.

In rendering you, Mr. President, the interpreter
of my sentiments, you will be pleased to accept the
expression of my gratitude due to your kind co-ope-
ration, and the delicacy of your proceedings. De-
voted as I am, by my travels and labors to the noble
destinies of the new continent, and taking the most
lively interest in the most direct and closest com-
mercial intercourse between the United States and
my country, I put the highest value on the honor
which you confer upon me in the decline of a life
which has had no other merit than that of a courage-
ous perseverance in the love of afor the good and freedom
of opinion.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to remain,
With the highest consideration,
Sir, your ob’t humble servant,
ALEX. DE HUMBOLDT.
